blog.description: Book reviews, book posts, and book jokes. Blog by Jana, 28, Texas. Currently Reading: The Lies of Locke Lamora (Gentlemen Bastards #1) by Scott Lynch

summary:
Book Review: Kingdom of Ash by Sarah J. Maas
(spoiler free for KOA)
title:
Book Review: Kingdom of Ash by Sarah J. Maas
(spoiler free for KOA)
body:
I don’t think there’s such a thing as an “objective” book review; we love books precisely because of the emotions they stir in our hearts. Reviewing Kingdom of Ash is more like me trying to describe my reaction to words on pages that I loved even as they ripped my heart to shreds and stitched it back together. From the moment I met infamous assassin Celaena Sardothien as she swaggered blindfolded through the halls of Endovier, this story reeled me in, but I could have never imagined the epic journey it would become. Kingdom of Ash was a glorious, heart-rending story of these people I have come to love fighting for a Better World.

Kingdom of Ash is the last stand of our Throne of Glass heroes against Erawan, his plan for the domination of Erilea and beyond finally unfolding, as he seeks destruction and oblivion for all who oppose him, and against Maeve, her true form revealed, her insidious plan manifesting as she fights gain control of Aelin to use her as she would for her own selfish ends. It is epic fantasy but compared to other books in that genre, it’s not as much a marathon as it is emotional sprint after sprint. It’s staggering and dramatic and alive and passionate. It doesn’t allow you a single second to catch your breath, not for all of its nearly-1000 pages.

With old debts called in and all cards on the table, this book takes so many characters we’ve come to know over the series and shows how their lives are threads woven together like a tapestry, and now we are pulling back to see the entire picture and how it will all end. I couldn’t even binge-read this book – I had to keep setting it down and taking time to process it all every few chapters just from the magnitude and the weight of the story. With all of its intense moments, it also had so many moments that made me laugh, and it held love (which SJM writes so perfectly) that made me just SIGH with happiness. The characters of this series are so real to me, their heartbreak and grief is painful, I celebrate their joys and triumphs, I love with them and I definitely cried with them.

I’ve been teary when I’ve read books before. I’ve been misty-eyed, I’ve had one dramatic Frodo-crying-for-Gandalf tear, I’ve maybe cried more once or twice ever from a book. This book had me crying multiple times (I went back and counted - six different scenes). At the end, I was weeping, like tear after tear and and shaky breathing and my husband giving me very concerned looks while I waved him away and trying to hold my heart together crying as I finished this series. I have no idea how Sarah J. Maas was able to wrap up this long story so well, and put this many emotions and heavy scene after scene onto paper. Did she just sob all day for the months it took her to write this?

But the Throne of Glass series has always been about getting up and about fighting for a Better World. It’s about hope in times of despair, and strength in the face of adversity. And the series is about amazing women who are badasses, who fight for what they believe in, who pursue what they want, who love fiercely, who use whatever strengths they have for themselves and for those they love, who lift each other up and refuse to settle. If I didn’t already love this series for the story with its twists that leave me gasping, I would love it for the women whose stories it tells. Aelin, Manon, Lysandra, Elide, Yrene, Nehemia, Asterin and the Thirteen, Evangeline, Ansel, Kaltain. They are passionate and they are ferocious and they love fiercely and they fight for what they believe in.

The bottom line is that I loved this book. Loved it. Easily and instantly, Kingdom of Ash has become one of my all-time favorites. Thank you, Sarah, for these books and characters (and even thank you for all of my emotions right now, wrecked as I am). If you haven’t read the series yet, stop what you’re doing and go pick up Throne of Glass right now.

@worldofsarahjmaas

+ bonus:  

I know not everyone loves prequels, but this series’ prequel is necessary to the plot, and it introduces many vital characters who you are delightfully surprised to re-encounter later on. In my opinion, the series like really starts with Heir of Fire anyway… if you’ve read it, you know why ;)

My suggested order to read in:

  • Throne of Glass
  • Crown of Midnight
  • Heir of Fire
  • Queen of Shadows
  • Assassin’s Blade
  • Empire of Storms
  • Tower of Dawn
  • Kingdom of Ash
  • My obituary, because this series killed me

title: Book Review: Tower of Dawn
body:
Book Review: Tower of Dawn

Tower of Dawn is the sixth book of the Throne of Glass series by Sarah J. Maas.

I bought Throne of Glass about 4-5 years ago and it sat on my bookshelf unread until finally last summer I decided to pick it up and read it. I was immediately mad at myself for not reading it sooner and quickly devoured books 1-5. When Tower of Dawn came out I had heard mixed reviews so I was hesitant to start…

View On WordPress

blog.name: we-are-rogue
blog.title: we are Rogue
blog.description:
Jack of all trades, master of none


Gallery | D&D | Fiction | Theory | Practice | Iconic | Tags and Masterposts

Inspiration and resources for Rogues, the most resourceful player class and fantasy archetype of them all.

Thieves, outlaws, rascals, scoundrels, pickpockets, cutpurses, cat burglars, bandits, con artists, assassins, infiltrators, spies, swashbucklers, highwaymen, smugglers, pirates, thugs, jesters, tricksters, skillmonkeys, specialists, factotums, and the occasional ronin: we are ROGUE.

summary:
Celaena Sardothien by 
Sophie Bangs

  “There
 is... this rage." she said "This despair and hatred and rage that lives
 and...
caption:
Celaena Sardothien by Sophie Bangs

“There is… this rage.“ she said "This despair and hatred and rage that lives and breathes inside me. There’s not sanity to it, no gentleness. It is a monster dwelling under my skin. For the past ten years, I have worked every day, every hour, to keep that monster locked up. And the moment I talk about those two days, and what happened before and after, that monster is going to break loose, and there will be no accounting for what I do.”

Celaena Sardothien from the Heir of Fire series by Sarah J. Maas.

a court of thorns and roses
summary:
“Fae”
“Winged male”
“Beautiful beyond reason”
“His starry sky”
“Dark power like a gentle summer night”
“A shield”
SAVING...
body:
WTF, RHYSAND???????

  • “Fae”
  • “Winged male”
  • “Beautiful beyond reason”
  • “His starry sky”
  • “Dark power like a gentle summer night”
  • “A shield”

THIS IS RHYSAND. FEYRE AND RHYS. WHAT THE FUCK. RHYSAND???

SAVING AELIN?????? Like one more reason for me to LOVE HIM as if I needed one but HOW????? I am DEAD

blog.name: anamgealach
blog.title: Noir Etoil
blog.description: Dreamer. Lives for literature. Various fandoms. Celtic Studies.

body:
Kingdom of Ash.

I finished the last of the books in the ToG series 3 hours ago. I still can’t find the words to even begin expressing my feelings, so this is a start. First of I’m so grateful to Sarah J. Maas for creating this world, for pursuing her dream of seeing the books published and finally for them coming to us the fans, to me as a human being. It was a long journey, but it was so extraordinary an meaningful (even when painful and in a way precisely because of that) that honestly I’m sad it came to an end, but all things do both good and bad. For me the last book couldn’t have been more perfect. I try to keep this post spoiler free, but the arcs of all of the characters were amazing. My favorite, ever since we first met her in HoF is Manon Blackbeak and her development especially in this final book undid me. I’m so proud and happy with what she became, who she became in this book that I have no words to express it. Every page of this book has been a delight. Every book in this and the ACOTAR series an inspiration, to keep moving forward, to keep fighting, to keep healing. Thank you Sarah for giving the world all of this. To the Author who listened and gave us hope for a better world.

reblog.comment:
Kingdom of Ash.

I finished the last of the books in the ToG series 3 hours ago. I still can’t find the words to even begin expressing my feelings, so this is a start. First of I’m so grateful to Sarah J. Maas for creating this world, for pursuing her dream of seeing the books published and finally for them coming to us the fans, to me as a human being. It was a long journey, but it was so extraordinary an meaningful (even when painful and in a way precisely because of that) that honestly I’m sad it came to an end, but all things do both good and bad. For me the last book couldn’t have been more perfect. I try to keep this post spoiler free, but the arcs of all of the characters were amazing. My favorite, ever since we first met her in HoF is Manon Blackbeak and her development especially in this final book undid me. I’m so proud and happy with what she became, who she became in this book that I have no words to express it. Every page of this book has been a delight. Every book in this and the ACOTAR series an inspiration, to keep moving forward, to keep fighting, to keep healing. Thank you Sarah for giving the world all of this. To the Author who listened and gave us hope for a better world.

blog.name: apileofgoodthings11
blog.title: A Pile of Good Things
blog.description: Former 10th grade English teacher and current teen librarian in a public library. Ask me for book recommendations, especially if you're looking for classroom library selections, curriculum help, and/or tie-ins!

summary:
1. I guess we know why A Court of Frost and Starlight is so short: KOA is 980 pages long! 
2. I’m only 383 pages in, but my...
body:
1. I guess we know why A Court of Frost and Starlight is so short: KOA is 980 pages long!

2. I’m only 383 pages in, but my emotions have already been brutalized!

3. I typically rush through books I love, but with this seventh and final installation, I find myself taking breaks because I don’t want it to end. Celeana/Aelin came into my life when it was pretty heinous, and she showed me how to stand up for myself and how to take my life into my own hands again. Kickass female protagonists always show up to guide me back to life, and I’m thankful I stumbled onto TOG.

4. Anyone else notice the assonance between Throne of GLASS, Kingdom of ASH, and Sarah J. MAAS? It makes my English major heart giddy. 😆

blog.name: wyrds-and-cauldrons
blog.title: Wyrds and Cauldrons
blog.description: Hi! Raena, Here! Welcome to my Massassin Court! Main: @bigmouthpanda

body:
Finished…

It’s done, I have finished Kingdom of Ash.

Honestly I feel like I have no words to describe how… I feel like this book will forever be apart of me.

Just as say Harry Potter is apart of so many others, this book is my Harry Potter. It is something that I strive to write.

Well done Sarah J Maas, well done this book is fantastic amazing beautiful a true work of lituature.

I had to express how I feel, I hope many agree with me in saying; Thank you thank you thank you, Sarah J Maas for writing this series…

*blinks five times*
